key_title: Key to the species of Ptilotus

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Amaranthaceae

source.author: Walsh, N.G.
source.title: Amaranthaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae
source.citation: Modified from: Walsh, N.G. (1996). Amaranthaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Plants greyish from a dense indumentum of stellate or dendritic hairs; aerial stems usually much-branched, plants often subshrubs; mallee areas only
Leaves and stems glabrous or somewhat pubescent, but not greyish overall, hairs simple or septate-barbed; stems prostrate or erect, but few-branched
Spikes 1.5–2 cm wide, dense; tepals silky-hairy all over outer surface; leaves whitish
Spikes 2.5–3 cm wide, rather loose; outer surfaces of tepals with long silky hairs in upper half only (but with much shorter branched hairs all over); leaves greyish or grey-green
Perianth yellow-green to straw-coloured at apex
Perianth pink or reddish at or near apex (but spike may appear coloured or whitish overall)
Flowering stems erect, 30 cm high or more, simple or few-branched
Flowering stems prostrate to ascending, to c. 30 cm high, usually several-branched (at least near base)
Perianth to 16 mm long; bracteoles rounded at apex; leaves retaining at least scattered hairs at maturity
Perianth 18 mm long or more; bracteoles acute, or obtuse and sometimes mucronate at apex; leaves glabrous at maturity
Leaves linear to narrowly obovate; bracts and bracteoles ± transparent, the bracteoles glabrous; perianth covered throughout with long, silky hairs; absent from far north-west
Leaves obovate to oblanceolate; bracts and bracteoles opaque about the mid-nerve, pubescent or tuberculate; perianth with long silky hairs confined to the upper half; far north-west only and rare

Outer surface of tepals glabrous in the lower quarter (except on margins and at very base); spikes remaining hemispherical to ovoid; basal leaves narrowly obovate, mostly more than 1 cm wide, the blade longer than the narrow base
Outer surface of tepals ± evenly hairy to base; spikes finally cylindric; basal leaves spathulate, mostly less than 1 cm wide, the narrow base much longer than the blade
Leaves linear or narrowly oblanceolate, to c. 3 mm wide; bracts pale straw-coloured or whitish; perianth ± curved upwards;
Leaves obovate to oblanceolate, the largest wider than 3 mm; bracts entirely brown or with a brown median stripe; perianth straight

Annual (or short-lived perennial) herbs with stems arising from a fleshy, little-branched taproot; basal leaves mostly 20–60 mm wide, shortly attenuate, usually distinctly mucronate; inflorescence cylindrical; mostly north-west mallee areas

Long-lived, perennating herbs, with annual stems arising from a much-branched, woody rootstock; basal leaves to c. 5 mm wide, long-attentuate, not or very shortly mucronate; inflorescence usually hemispherical or ovoid (rarely cylindrical); mostly Wimmera
